data.title: France/Italy/United States : Agnelli family, Kering both coveted Versace and Jimmy Choo before Tapestry takeover
data.meta_description: Tapestry's summer acquisition of Capri, the Versace and Jimmy Choo parent, followed talks with Exor, the Agnelli family's fund, and luxury giant Kering. Glitz.paris has pieced together the episodes, - 9/14/2023
data.text:
Read also

Spotlight | France

Pinault family splashes out in hope of offsetting losses

With the slump in Kering's performance threatening to eat into dividends, the Pinault family - its principal shareholder - is investing heavily to diversify its family office. Its other traditional sources of revenue, such as wine, tourism and art, are also becoming less bankable.

Subscribers only Families

United States

Tapestry defends its merger with Capri using the LVMH-Tiffany example

US luxury group Tapestry's merger with Capri Holdings has been blocked by a complaint from the Federal Trade Commission, concerned about the risk of a handbag monopoly. Tapestry has hit back and accused the regulator of inconsistency, given it authorised a similar merger in the jewellery sector when LVMH bought out Tiffany's.

Free access Entourage

France, Italy

Valentino makes fashion show deal with crumbling Beaux-Arts

The Italian fashion house has signed an exclusive contract with the Parisian art school to hold its shows there. It's a major coup for the Beaux-Arts, which is badly in need of the rental income.

Free access Entourage

France, Italy

Christian Louboutin's social and environmental unit faces staff cuts

The French shoe manufacturer is making drastic cuts to its social and environmental responsibility department, which has a poor track record.

Subscribers only Houses

France, Italy

Kering board nominee opened Italian museum to luxury groups

Kering will put forward Giovanna Melandri's name to shareholders next month to replace outgoing board member Emma Watson, whose departure Glitz.paris foretold in January. The former Italian culture minister built bridges between the art and luxury worlds as head of Rome's Maxxi modern art museum.

Subscribers only Houses

United States

Capri executives land golden parachutes

Jenna Hendricks, senior vice president of Capri Holdings, which owns Versace, Jimmy Choo and other luxury brands, has received a generous bonus for remaining with the company after its merger with Tapestry.

Subscribers only Houses

Italy, United States

Diane von Fürstenberg adopts Venice as her part-time home, following in François Pinault's footsteps

American fashion designer Diane von Fürstenberg is the latest luxury heavyweight to set down her bags in the Italian city, a move facilitated by family ties.

Subscribers only Families

United States

Tapestry takeover: Capri Holdings seeks to reassure staff at Versace, Jimmy Choo and Michael Kors

A few weeks after the announcement of the merger with Tapestry, employees of the fashion brands involved are concerned about their future. Capri, the holding company that made the sale, has been trying to put their minds at ease.

Subscribers only Houses

Spotlight | France

Behind the resurrection of Karl Lagerfeld's former Paris mansion

Home to Chanel's former artistic director Karl Lagerfeld for over 30 years, the 18th-century mansion on Paris's Rue de l'Université is gradually inviting the world of luxury back inside. Driving this revival has been its owner, the state of Gabon.

Subscribers only Entourage

Italy, United States

John Galantic set to stick with Ferrari after leaving Chanel

After heading Chanel Inc in the US since 2006, John Galantic will leave the luxury group at the end of this month. But he will remain on the board at Ferrari.

Subscribers only Houses

Spotlight | France

Luxury heavyweights jockey for position with Jacquemus

Boasting rising sales and growing appeal among younger consumers, Simon Porte Jacquemus's company is an inviting prospect for major luxury groups. But for now, the young designer's desire for independence has kept their approaches at bay.

Free access Houses

France

François-Henri Pinault drops off the radar

François-Henri Pinault is making sure his travels don't show up on flight-tracking websites. The Kering CEO, who has owned a large-cabin private jet for two years, is keen to avoid the fate that befell Bernard Arnault, who was famously obliged to give up his own aircraft under pressure from plane-spotters tracking his movements.

Free access Families
